body: Please explain and provide a test for your assumption. Because when apply_async throws an error we do not recover from that
Please check your commit message. It does not refer the Jira issue and your commit message does not follow the guidelines. After that is fixed it can be merged.

@bolkedebruin 
In my case, I was using redis as celery broker. When redis was down and a task was ready to execute, the scheduler first add the task to **running** queue, then **apply_async** will failed and throw exception, the scheduler was continue to check next time , but the task in **running** queue was considered running and never call **apply_async** again because relevant code: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/executors/base_executor.py#L48

This case was easy to reproduce.
Step 1, kill the celery broker.
Step 2, start the scheduler(celery executor), make sure tasks will be call apply_async
Step 3, start celery broker, new tasks was fine to executed,  but the tasks called by apply_async in step 2 will be lost and never be executed.
Step 4, because of "running" queue, restart scheduler will make the lost tasks apply_async again and be executed.

@sleep1661 apply_async from celery will throw an error if it can't connect which we don't catch. It does make sense to set running only after apply_async, but the issue you are describing I would like to see tested. So please provide a test that 

1. Mimics a failed/non working celery broker
2. Tries to schedule a task
3. Doesn't fail entirely (ie. scheduler does not stop)
4. Bring celery broker back up again
5. Schedule a task successfully.
Have edited it an created a new pull request at https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2812

Important change in the PR to fix a bug coming from a misunderstanding of how jenkins attribute build number. The build number is given only once the job get executed and not when the job is getting triggered, so we need to poll the jenkins queue until the job execution start for that. 
This required to change slightly the way a request is sent to jenkins as the location in the queue is only present in the response headers. 
It is now fixed and I'm currently testing it. I hope @larrywongl will be able to test it in a state closer to airflow current HEAD (I'm using airflow 1.8.1 so the logging mechanism is slightly different, but normally I have take care of that :) )

>>> import airflow.settings
